parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several methods have shown effectiveness in reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 2]: Specific cost-effectiveness data for methods to reduce unwanted catch was not provided in the available evidence.
[Statement 3]: Size-sorting mesh funnels, also known as sieve nets, on prawn and shrimp trawls consistently reduced unwanted fish catches in North Sea studies.
[Statement 4]: Trawl gear modifications with size-sorting escape grids reduced unwanted catches in 6 of 16 studies.
[Statement 5]: The effectiveness of trawl gear modifications with size-sorting escape grids varied by fish species, light conditions, and net type.
[Statement 6]: Alternative fishing methods like traps showed mixed results for reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 7]: Alternative fishing methods like traps also reduced commercial catch in some cases.
[Statement 8]: Governance approaches showed promise in reducing unwanted catch.
[Statement 9]: Catch limits or quotas for non-commercial species reduced unwanted catch in 2 of 3 cases across the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
[Statement 10]: Real-time catch information technology reduced unwanted catch in 2 of 3 cases in the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans.
[Statement 11]: The documents lack specific cost-benefit analyses to determine which method for reducing unwanted catch is most economically efficient.
[Statement 12]: The documents focused on biological effectiveness instead of economic efficiency.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the most cost-effective method for reducing unwanted catch in commercial fisheries?
